dimensions.name: Concept Clarity
dimensions.description: How clearly the teacher explains operating system concepts such as processes, threads, memory management, and file systems.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Uses simple definitions; illustrates concepts with real‑world OS examples (e.g., how a scheduler works).
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Provides vague or contradictory explanations; jumps between topics like virtualization and paging without clear links.

dimensions.name: Delivery & Communication
dimensions.description: Voice clarity, pacing, energy, and engagement when presenting OS material.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Clear voice, varied tone, steady pace; uses diagrams and live demos to reinforce points.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Monotone voice, speaks too fast during code walkthroughs; excessive filler words that obscure key ideas.

dimensions.name: Content Structure
dimensions.description: Logical flow of OS lessons: introduction → core concept → concrete example → summary.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Starts with an overview of process lifecycle, then demonstrates a scheduling algorithm, and ends with a recap of key takeaways.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Randomly jumps from virtual memory to device drivers without transitions; lacks a clear beginning or conclusion.

dimensions.name: Student Engagement
dimensions.description: Interaction with learners, prompting questions, and using relevant OS scenarios.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: Asks probing questions like “What happens when a process exceeds its memory quota?” and checks understanding with quick polls.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Delivers a one‑way lecture with no questions, ignores student confusion about synchronization primitives.

dimensions.name: Accuracy
dimensions.description: Correctness of information about operating system theory and implementations.
dimensions.examplesOfGood: All statements about kernel modes, system calls, and deadlock conditions are factually correct.
dimensions.examplesOfBad: Misstates that RAM is non‑volatile; incorrectly describes how page tables are updated.
